newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican coffee growers seek certification support.
newsitem.headline: Mexican coffee growers seek certification support.

text.p: A group of Mexican coffee growers, looking to shake off the country's age-old poor bean quality image and punitive pricing, are battling to get their coffee certified in order to tap credit lines.

The growers, who are ready to tap $20 million in fresh credits that the Mexico City-based Union de Credito Para la Eficiencia Empresarial (UCEE) is making available, are being thwarted because of a lack of certifying agents and a lack of certifying culture.

UCEE coordinator Ignacio Luyando told Reuters Monday that around 6,000 growers from the states of Chiapas, Oaxaca, Veracruz, Puebla and Guerrero, together producing around 92,000 60-kg bags of coffee, faced the problem.

One difficulty is that recognised Mexican certifiers are on the whole linked to coffee buyers in Mexico, often causing a conflict of interest to certify beans a specific quality, which would automatically mean higher prices.
Mexican coffee is traditionally hit by punitive prices given its long-standing production of inferior quality beans compared to other arabica producers in the region, such as Guatemala.
Luyando believes Mexico needs a new generation of coffee certifyers and has called on the international coffee community to help out the growers lining up to sign up for credits with the UCEE.
"We have written to the Green Coffee Association in New York, pointing out the problem and asking how we can get suitable certification services," Luyando said.

The growers, producing high altitude, prime washed and extra prime beans, need the certifications to guarantee floor prices for loans taken out through the UCEE, a hybrid company offering loans and farm consultancy services.
